videos.title: What Can You Write After an Augmented 6th Chord? - Music Composition
videos.description:
This music composition lesson begins with a reminder of how to form an augmented 6th chord with its three variants, the Italian French and German 6ths. The video goes on to explain which are the most common resolution chords, considering the reasons why these chords work better than other options, examining voice leading, the smooth progression of parts, and the avoidance of parallels & false relations. This video will empower you to use augmented 6th chords in context and demonstrates why they are essentially pre dominant chords.

videos.title: Using Suspensions to Harmonize a Descending Bass - Music Composition
videos.description:
Here's an idea for writing a sequence based on using a chain of suspensions above a descending scale in the bass line. Descending scales in the bass can be awkward to harmonise satisfactorily without generating parallels. This pattern illustrates one way of handling the situation in a way that is musically interesting and which activates an engaging use of musical tension. These kind of structures are useful for composers working in any genre and are especially for building bridges or other connections between musical ideas.

This lesson explains the opening structure and examines clues for interpretation provided by Brahms in a letter he wrote about this work to Clara Schumann. videos.title: Composing in Sonata Form - What is Sonata Form?
videos.description:
Unravel the intricacies of Sonata Form, the preferred form for the first movement of sonatas, symphonies, and concertos. This lesson provides a comprehensive journey into the intricacies of the Sonata Form as well as potential options for alternative structures. We look at key details regarding key movement, repeated subjects, section, themes and the overall development of ideas.

⬇️Download the files

0:57 - Exposition section
8:57 - Development section
14:00 - Recapitulation section
19:12 - Conclusion

🎓 Composing in Sonata Form Course
Start writing extended pieces, develop material and learn how to compose music using Sonata Form. Sonata Form serves as the catalyst for honing your composition skills and nurturing your growth as a proficient music creator. This course begins with an explanation of Sonata Form - what it is and how it evolved during the Classical Period. We then analyse Sonata Form movements written by Mozart and Beethoven to discover how Classical Period composers wrote in this structure and in order to see how Sonata Form was to develop during the Romantic Period. The course also explains the possible variants within Sonata Form that composers might choose to explore. There follow two composition projects. In the first, we write the essentials of a Sonata Form movement in the Classical Period style, considering how to compose first and second subjects, how to develop and recapitulate material, when to include an introduction, a Coda and transition material. In the second, we write a more extended Sonata Form movement in a more contemporary style, learning to deal with the challenges of working with Sonata Form in an atonal environment.

videos.title: How to Write a Crab Canon - Writing Canon
videos.description:
Learn the meaning of ‘crab canon’ then proceeds to compose an example so you can see how to do it. In a crab canon, one part works forwards while a second part simultaneously works the same music in reverse. This means that one part has to be designed melodically, rhythmically and harmonically to work with the other part while following the principles of crab canon. Watch this video to discover the technique of writing a crab canon.

videos.title: Changing Harmony from Major to Minor - Music Theory
videos.description:
Discover how to harmonise the same melody in either a major key or a minor key. In many cases the implied tonality is obvious when one looks at a melodic line. Sometimes it isn’t entirely clear if a melodic phrase should be harmonised in a major key or in the relative minor. This music theory lesson starts with a melodic line and demonstrates how it can be harmonised equally successfully in both G major and E minor.

videos.title: Using Chords in the Natural Minor - Music Theory
videos.description:
Many people are comfortable working in the harmonic and melodic keys when harmonising a melodic line but feel less assured doing the same in the natural minor. In this music theory lesson we explore which chords are major, which are minor, and which are diminished. We consider how the chord lineup is different from the chord lineup in the harmonic and melodic minors. We go on to observe the harmonisation of a melody in the natural minor and consider how different the music feels when we contrast harmonisations in the natural minor with harmonisations using the harmonic minor. This video will free you up to harmonise with confidence in the natural minor.

videos.title: Conjunct and Disjunct Melody Writing - Music Composition
videos.description:
What is meant by the terms conjunct and disjunct in relation to melody writing? We listen to and look at one melody written entirely using conjunct movement and consider its merits & weaknesses. We then do the same in relation to a melody written entirely using disjunct movement. Finally we consider a melody written combining conjunct and disjunct movement and evaluate the best way of doing so. This music composition lesson will enhance your ability to evaluate the construction of a melody in terms of conjunct and disjunct movement and will help you to compose successful melodies.

We examine the choice of harmony and modulation, the part writing, the use of accented and unaccented passing notes, plus other features of the Bach Chorale style. Useful for anyone wanting to improve their ability to write harmony, to analyse harmony, or to understand the detail of Bach’s style. Join us on this exciting journey to delve inside the mind of the great J.S.Bach.

videos.title: Should You Avoid Using II to I Chord Progressions? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive/ parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: When Should You Use Second Inversion Chords? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Why do second inversion chords demand special treatment? Starting with an explanation of why root position and first inversion chords are stable in themselves we are introduced to 6/4 5/3 progressions and passing 6/4 chords, as the safest places to employ second inversion chords.  Specific examples are explored so you can see and hear how and why second inversions require resolution and how best to make them work.

videos.title: 4 Chord Progressions to Avoid - Music Theory
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using certain chord progressions. Why is that? This music theory lesson explains how the chord progressions under consideration can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progressions are best avoided at cadence points. We consider the smooth progression of individual voices and how certain progressions create awkward leaps and we hear examples where alternative choices of chords generate more convincing outcomes. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use each of the progressions successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use these progressions or not.

videos.title: Harmony Using Primary Chords - Music Composition
videos.description:
In this music theory lesson we look at three melodies, each capable of being harmonised using only primary chords. The video shows how to treat the melody notes as chord tones or as non-chord tones, and how to find primary chords to fit. The chords are presented in both lead sheet style and in Roman Numerals. We then move on to think about how to present the chords in keyboard style. This video will be useful to players and composers alike.

videos.title: Piano to Organ - What do You Need to Know? The Keyboards Pedalboard, Stops, Swell box and Couplers
videos.description:
Are you a pianist wanting to play the organ? Ever wondered how an organ works? This informative lesson breaks down the complexities of the instrument, from its multiple keyboards to its intricate stop system. Learn about the differences between the Great, Swell, and Choir organs, the role of the pedalboard, and the function of stops like flutes, diapasons, and reeds. Discover the unique sounds and techniques that make the organ such a powerful and versatile instrument.

videos.title: Why Not Use a V-II Chord Progression? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: The Harmonic Series Explained - Music Theory
videos.description:
Join us and discover the harmonic series, or overtone series. This music theory lesson begins with a fundamental note and explains how to derive the overtones from that note that comprise the harmonic series. The video uses the principles of brass playing as a guide to how it all works and lists the first 16 notes of a harmonic series based on C as a fundamental note. We go on to learn how the valves and the slide work on brass instruments in order to capture every semitone / half step of the chromatic scale by combining different transpositions of the harmonic series. We also discover how these overtones enrich the sound of the fundamental note.

videos.title: The Difference Between Major and Minor Pentatonic Scales - Music Theory
videos.description:
We begin with a reminder of what is a pentatonic scale and how a pentatonic scale can be transposed. We go on to hear and look at a short melody written in C major pentatonic before comparing that with another melody written in A minor pentatonic. We see and hear how the tonic of the two melodies differs and how that enables us to define the melody as major pentatonic or minor pentatonic. This music theory lesson will be useful to those playing in major pentatonic and minor pentatonic and will also help those who are writing in major and minor pentatonic.

videos.title: Why Does it Matter How We Spell Musical Notes? - Music Theory
videos.description:
We consider the spelling of notes, or enharmonics. Why do notes have more than one name? How do we know when to call a note Gb or F# or even E double sharp? This music theory lesson explains why the spelling of notes matters and gets into the reasons why it might be right to choose one spelling of a note over another. We examine a melody and a passage of harmony where correct spellings and incorrect spellings appear.

videos.title: Is VI-I a Good Chord Progression? - Music Composition
videos.description:
Harmony text books often advise us to avoid using this particular chord progression. Why is that? This music composition lesson explains how this chord progression can create difficulties in the part writing with consecutive / parallel fifths and octaves and also explains why the progression is best avoided at cadence points. The video goes on to demonstrate how to use the progression more successfully and explores why style, mood and musical context make an impact on the choice to use this progression or not.

videos.title: Cool Extended Chord Progressions - Music Composition
videos.description:
You may be someone who is used to using certain chords over and over again or you may be someone who is confident using diatonic chords but who is reluctant to explore more colourful harmony. This lesson explores the impact of 7th, 9th, 11th and 13th chords, covering possibilities for voicing those chords, how one extended chord might best progress to another, how you might impose a melody or a moving bass on an extended chord progression, and different things you could do with the texture. Conventional and less conventional progressions are investigated, along with chromatic alterations to extended notes within the chord. In short this series of videos will open your mind to new possibilities and encourage you to explore more. For many viewers this will be a real game changer. This video belongs to a set of 8 videos focused on using extended chords to create more colourful harmony.

videos.title: How to Write in Parallel, Contrary, Oblique and Similar Motion - Voice Leading
videos.description:
Dive into the fascinating world of voice leading, a vital skill for composers and musicians. Learn how to craft harmonious interactions between musical parts, whether they're sung, played by instruments, or performed on a keyboard. This lesson unveils the four fundamental techniques of voice leading—parallel motion, contrary motion, oblique motion, and similar motion—with clear examples and practical tips for creating beautiful, cohesive music. Ideal for anyone looking to enhance their compositional skills, this is the first in a 12-part series designed to deepen your understanding of this essential musical concept.
